awd_titl_txt: Resolving Time-Dependent Atmospheric Dynamics on Jupiter and Saturn with Improved Planetary Cloud-Tracking Wind Measurement Methods
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our overarching goals in our project are to improve remote-sensing wind-measurement methods, and to examine the time-dependent atmospheric dynamics of Jupiter and Saturn.  Jupiter and Saturn both have extremely active atmospheres that harbor many jetstreams that blow in east-west directions, and vortices that drift between the jets. The dynamics of these atmospheric jets and vortices can be measured using space-based remote sensing instruments through analysis of the temporal evolution of the clouds. The horizontal motions of the clouds yield information about the horizontal wind vectors. New clouds appear where there is vertical upwelling, while clouds tend to disappear where there is a downwelling. Thus, detailed examination of cloud evolution can reveal horizontal and vertical motions in the atmosphere.

Specific goals of our project are to develop and improve a new cloud-tracking analysis code using modern image-processing methods, and to make atmospheric dynamics measurements on Jupiter and Saturn.

The goal to improve cloud-tracking wind measurement tools have been achieved through an effort to improve the quantification of the measurement uncertainties. Before our development effort, almost all cloud-tracking tools use the zonal standard deviation (i.e., standard deviation in each latitude bin) as a proxy for measurement uncertainty. The use of the standard deviation is based on the fact that, in most planetary atmospheres, the variation of dynamical quantities in the north-south (i.e., meridional) direction is much greater than those in the east-west (zonal) direction. The use of the standard deviation as a proxy for the measurement uncertainty essentially assumes that the zonal scatter is negligible, and any variance in the measurement is caused by measurement noise. For modern high-resolution remote-sensing wind measurements, this assumption often does not hold, and the zonal standard deviation contains both spatial variation and measurement uncertainties. Thus, one significant outcome of our project is the development of a method to quantitatively separate the real spatial variation from measurement uncertainty.

The goal to examine the time-dependent atmospheric dynamics on Jupiter and Saturn has taken advantage of new opportunities and student interests. Images of Saturn captured by NASA’s Cassini spacecraft’s Imaging Science Subsystem (ISS) camera between 2004 and 2017 has revealed a wealth of time-dependent phenomena – we applied the newly developed cloud tracking method to the vast Cassini image set to study the seasonal evolution of Saturn’s atmospheric dynamics. We also analyzed Jupiter’s wind evolution through measuring the wind speed in 2000 using images captured by Cassini, and in 2007 by the New Horizons spacecraft. We also applied the cloud-tracking tool to analyze winds on Venus using images captured by the European Space Agency’s Venus Express spacecraft, and Japanese Aerospace Exploration Agency’s Akatsuki orbiter. The arrival of Juno Spacecraft at Jupiter in 2016 also brought an opportunity to analyze the new data; consequently, we have incorporated analysis of new Juno data to our project.

Modified by: Kunio M Sayanagi
